awd_titl_txt: REU Site: BME Community of Undergraduate Research Scholars for Cancer (BME CUReS Cancer)
awd_abstract_narration:
The BME Community of Undergraduate Research Scholars for Cancer (BME CUReS Cancer) REU Site at the University of Texas (UT) at Austin will provide opportunities for a diverse group of talented undergraduates traditionally underrepresented in engineering to make contributions towards the fundamental understanding of the physical principles of cancer development, prevention, and treatment during a ten-week summer research experience. An aim of this research experience is that the Scholars will be inspired to go on in their careers to function in multi-disciplinary teams of researchers from disparate fields in engineering, medicine, biological science, physical science, and healthcare fields to advance human health. The Site's partnership with the UT Medical School and Texas 4000, a non-profit organization that cultivates student leaders and engages communities in the fight against cancer, will help to increase public awareness of cancer research, in particular how physical science and engineering positively impact healthcare.

Cancer is a disease of complexity and engineering principles in particular are developed to study, model, and solve complex problems. The scientific theme of the BME CUReS Cancer Site is leveraging Biomedical Engineering to Open a New Frontier in Oncology. BME CUReS Cancer Scholars will be matched with a project of appropriate scope from 35 different laboratories representing a wide range of research topics pertinent to cancer research, such as biomaterials, drug delivery, optical imaging, medical imaging, and artificial intelligence in medicine. These topics were selected in response to the barriers to achieving progress in cancer research that have been identified by the National Cancer Institute. It is now broadly recognized that understanding how the range of physical laws and principles governing the behavior of all matter are operative in cancer at every scale will be critical to understanding and controlling cancer. Cancer is a disease of complexity and engineering principles in particular are developed to study, model, and solve complex problems. Biomedical Engineering is uniquely poised to make a significant intellectual contribution to addressing these key challenges in cancer
research using an engineering approach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

perf_inst.perf_str_addr: 107 W. Dean Keeton St. Stop C080

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
We implemented an innovative NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates Site entitled, “BME Community of Undergraduate Research Scholars for Cancer,” or “BME CUReS Cancer.” We ran this program for four summers, for 10 weeks each summer, from late May to early August. We targeted rising sophomores, focusing particularly on students from groups traditionally underrepresented in engineering. The scientific theme of the “BME Community of Undergraduate Research Scholars for Cancer (BME CUReS Cancer),” REU Site was to train engineering and other quantitative science researchers to focus on cancer-related problems by building a community of cancer researchers, understanding that all participants of this community would benefit. BME CUReS Cancer Scholars chose a project of appropriate scope from 36 different labs representing a wide range of research topics pertinent to cancer research. We collaborated with Texas 4000, a non-profit organization that cultivates student leaders and engages communities in the fight against cancer.

 

Intellectual Merit. The scientific community now recognizes how physical and mathematical principles governing the behavior of all matter are operative in cancer at every scale. The ability to describe such phenomena will be critical in understanding and controlling cancer. Cancer is a disease of complexity and engineering principles in particular are useful to study, model and solve complex problems. Hence, Biomedical Engineering is uniquely poised to make a significant intellectual contribution towards solving problems in oncology. We have identified critical lines of investigation to organize our community of cancer Scholars towards shared goals and synergistic activities. The intellectual merit of this application is in addressing these key challenges in cancer research using an engineering approach. Our Site gave Scholars a real-world experience as a researcher by submitting an abstract and participating in the poster session in the undergraduate session of the Biomedical Engineering Society annual conference. Pre- and post-surveys showed significant gains from the beginning to the end of the summer program in Scientific Writing items including “Write and submit an abstract to a scientific meeting” and “Write with minimal help because your skills are strong enough". In focus groups, Scholars emphasized skill development and understanding how to manage research and plan for delays.

 

Broader Impacts. It is an underlying theme of our reported Site that CUReS Cancer Scholars made contributions towards fundamental understanding of these physical principles during their summer experience. Growth in measures of Scholars' self-efficacy and identity were observed in pre- and post-surveys. Substantive gains were made in Researcher Self-Concept. More importantly, Scholars have gone on in their careers to function in multi-disciplinary teams of researchers from disparate fields in medicine, biological science, physical science, engineering, and healthcare fields to advance human health. This ability is a hallmark of Biomedical Engineering and will positively impact Scholars respective scientific fields as well as the health of our society. Increasing the number of PhDs from underrepresented groups is also a critical step toward increasing minority role models, in turn making academic engineering culture more appealing to underrepresented minorities and women. Furthermore, our partnership with the Texas 4000 increased public awareness of cancer research, in particular how physical science and engineering positively impact healthcare.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2022
Modified by: Mia K Markey
por.por_txt_cntn:
We implemented an innovative NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates Site entitled, "BME Community of Undergraduate Research Scholars for Cancer," or "BME CUReS Cancer." We ran this program for four summers, for 10 weeks each summer, from late May to early August. We targeted rising sophomores, focusing particularly on students from groups traditionally underrepresented in engineering. The scientific theme of the "BME Community of Undergraduate Research Scholars for Cancer (BME CUReS Cancer)," REU Site was to train engineering and other quantitative science researchers to focus on cancer-related problems by building a community of cancer researchers, understanding that all participants of this community would benefit. BME CUReS Cancer Scholars chose a project of appropriate scope from 36 different labs representing a wide range of research topics pertinent to cancer research. We collaborated with Texas 4000, a non-profit organization that cultivates student leaders and engages communities in the fight against cancer.

It is an underlying theme of our reported Site that CUReS Cancer Scholars made contributions towards fundamental understanding of these physical principles during their summer experience. Furthermore, our partnership with the Texas 4000 increased public awareness of cancer research, in particular how physical science and engineering positively impact healthcare.
